subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Hamon description

Hi Ron,

 

Its an nagai-ashi gunome. There is another description the would be
translated as "the long ashi approach the ha," but the exact Japanese
wording escapes me at the moment.

 

Gordon

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...] 
Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 9:12 AM
To: TOKEN; nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Hamon description

 

Hi all - 

A very small attachment shows what I've asked about. Hope it clears okay. If
not, ask and I'll send it individually to anyone interested.

Ron
STL
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Gordon Robson 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Friday, July 23, 2004 6:29 PM
  Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Hamon description


  Hi Ron,



  Hako-midare, ko-ashi hataraku might be closer, but a picture would help.



  Gordon



  -----Original Message-----
  From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...] 
  Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 1:25 AM
  To: TOKEN; nihontostudy; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Hamon description



  Curious about the correct way to describe a particular style of hamon
which
  I'd describe as a smallish gunome with ko-ashi, in groups of five or six
  gunome. Each section of gunome is seperated with a slightly larger ashi,
  which while subtle, does make the straight gunmome hamon appear in
"groups"
  of gunome. Hope that is clear.

  One term I find is called "sugu ashi iri" which I take to mean, "suguha
  containing ashi." 

  The pattern I'm trying to describe would see (to me) correctly described
as
  something like "sugu kaku (boxed) gunome ashi iri" or am I sounding too
  midwestern with my Japanese??  Any comments?  If a small sketch (file)
would
  help, I'll send one out.

  Ron
  STL
